To proof.
[Melbourne,]
editorial addition.
August [6th 1862]
editorial addition — date of previous and subsequent letters in sequence.

Herewith I have the honor to hand you a sketch of the pigeon which you kindly promised to send Mr J. B. Stair of Broadmeadows.
At a Council meeting of the Acclimatisation Society of Victoria, 5 August 1862, 'A letter was read from The Revd J. B. Stair of Broadmeadows addressed to the Vice President concerning the pigeon of which a sketch had been sent by His Excellency. Dr Mueller was requested to reply and to forward to Mr Stair one of the copies which have been made of this bird.' (Unit 1, p. 224, VPRS 2223, PROV). As this is the only copy left here the Council will request that Mr Stair return it at his convenience.
At a Council meeting, 12 August 1862, 'Letters were laid before the Council by the Vice President which he had received from the Revd J. B. Stair, clergyman at Broadmeadows concerning the pigeon from the Navigator Islands of which enquiries are bieng made by His Excellency Sir Henry Barkly. Mr Stair who resided on these islands for many years at once recognied the sketh furnished by the Zoological ociety of London as a drawing of the "Manu Mea" or red bird of Samoa. Mr Stair states that these birds are very scarce and pointed out the best way in his opinion to procure them — copies of which the Secretary was requested to send Mr Williams and inform him that the Society would be happy to defray any expense he might be put to in procuring the bird.' (Unit 1, p. 227, VPRS 2223, PROV).

I would also venture to request that you will inform me of the name of the British Consul at Suez so that I may write to him about the Angora goats, as proposed by yourself.
